posts.cooked:
[Y] I have searched open and closed issues for duplicates

Issue Description

Background

I use signal for most messaging, and most are not needing expiry dates. Specifically, having a long history is beneficial. This history includes many images. The result of this is that my Signal backup file is now 2.57GB in size, with each file having a different name.

Problem

  • It is now very slow to backup.
  • It impacts available storage (or the number of backups that can be kept).
  • Copying backup files to cloud storage is also slow and unreliable due to size.

Suggested Solution

Any one of:

  • Incremental backups to new file: just backup what was changed since the last (incremental or full) backup.
  • Time-based backups: allow the user to say “Only backup what changed since time T” (poor-man’s incremental)

What would be involved?

  • Allowing for multiple backups files to be created
  • Allowing for multiple backup files to be restored
  • If it’s not already done, then each message would need a date and an invariant (across backup/restore) unique ID

In the simplest implementation, each backup file would be a self-contained backup with a date-of-backup. Ideally (but not essential) it should be able to be restored at any time, not just at app-install time (see below).

Possible problems

  • Missing backup files: the backup storage implementation should not rely on a complete set of files. Files should be independent. In the case of conflict for a given message or setting, the most recent (according to internal backup date) should be used.
  • I’m guessing there’s a reason why backups can only be restored at install-time. Revisiting this choice might be beneficial (see below), although processing multiple files at this time would be sufficient to alleviate the problem.

Benefits

It completely addresses the issues raised initially (after the first huge backup file is sent to the cloud):

  • Fast backup.
  • Substantially reduced storage consumption.
  • Improved cloud sync reliability.

Allowing multiple files may also make the following possible:

  • Restoring missing messages from Desktop version as well as app version (a merge)
  • Merging data from two devices (if one has been used temporarily while another was being repaired)

link_counts.title: Backups: Why I can't get family and friends onto Signal
Increase Backup Speed (e.g. by dividing backups into chucks which can be easily archived)
Pause backups and allow different backup schedules

posts.name: Filip Parag
posts.cooked:
It looks like this issue isn’t being worked on, or at least there is no recent activity on the forum.

I completely with agree with the proposed ideas and would like to add that with the introduction of new groups (v2) this just becomes an even greater issue.

My backups are duplicated daily using Syncthing and I had to delete a lot of old pictures to prevent it from eating my limited mobile internet when there is no WiFi in sight.

This doesn’t become an problem for users right away, so it doesn’t look as incentivizing as adding new flashy features.

Also a good idea would be “yearly” backups.
Instead of creating a single monolithic file, each year would get it’s own file, properly timestamped.

From a restore-perspective “split”-backups could be handled on an ‘on available’-base.
When the user restores, he or she specifies a folder with the backup(s). Each backup-file should be self containing and a valid backup for the given year. As long as the passphrase used to create the backup matches to the other backup-files, it should be added to the “restore”.

This not only reduces the size to regularly backup (since only the current year file changes) but also the ability to NOT restore older years, while keeping the ability to restore them at a later date (as long as the phrase is the same. Maybe the backupfiles do need an indicator that they belong together in this case)

This can also be applied to any other incremental backup.

Edit:
The current year could be handled like it currently gets handled, so that there is still an option to have “timestamped” backups.

posts.name: Jan
posts.cooked:
See also:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

introduce chunked backups

signalapp:main ← Roghetti:backup-chunking
opened 10:25PM - 15 Jan 22 UTC
Roghetti
+1237 -59

### First time contributor checklist - [x] I have read [how to contribute](ht…tps://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) to this project - [x] I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://whispersystems.org/cla/) ### Contributor checklist - [x] I am following the [Code Style Guidelines](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/wiki/Code-Style-Guidelines) - [x] I have tested my contribution on these devices: * Oneplus 3, Android 9 * Virtual device, Android 9 * Virtual device, Android 11 - [x] My contribution is fully baked and ready to be merged as is - [x] I ensure that all the open issues my contribution fixes are mentioned in the commit message of my first commit using the `Fixes #1234` [syntax](https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/) ---------- ### Description I work for bevuta IT GmbH, a company based in Germany. Our boss is a Signal user on Android. He has the problem that he can't backup his Signal app data to the SD card and despite 128 GB of internal memory, he no longer has free internal storage, mainly because of the signal backups. The most reasonable explanation was that his Android version doesn't support file systems other than FAT32 on SD cards. FAT32 has some limitations, such as a maximum file size of ~4 GB. His Signal installation uses more than 4 GB. To us, the use of a sd card for backups also seems advantageous, as it is easier to get at the data if the device breaks down. We discussed several solutions. The best solution we came up with, is to just chunk the Signal backup into parts smaller than 4 GB, if desired. I was tasked to implement it. To use this code in a real Signal installation, it has to be in the official release. Now, here is my MR! :-)

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

Large backup to FAT does not warn user of unsuccessful backup

opened 03:03PM - 02 Feb 22 UTC
janvlug
acknowledged

<!-- This is a bug report template. By following the instructions below and fill…ing out the sections with your information, you will help the developers get all the necessary data to fix your issue. You can also preview your report before submitting it. You may remove sections that aren't relevant to your particular case. Before we begin, please note that this tracker is only for issues. It is not for questions, comments, or feature requests. If you would like to discuss a new feature or submit suggestions, please visit the community forum: https://community.signalusers.org If you are looking for support, please visit our support center: https://support.signal.org/ or email support@signal.org Let's begin with a checklist: Replace the empty checkboxes [ ] below with checked ones [x] accordingly. --> - [x] I have searched open and closed issues for duplicates - [x] I am submitting a bug report for existing functionality that does not work as intended - [x] I have read https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports - [x] This isn't a feature request or a discussion topic ---------------------------------------- ### Bug description When you create a backup of a large > 4.3 GB Signal database to an as "portable" formatted (I guess FAT32) SD-card, a partial backup file is created of 4.3 GB instead of a full backup. The user does not get a warning, and thinks that they have a good backup, which is not the case. The restore of the partial backup did not get messages back, changed my safety number and disconnected my linked devices. I consider this as a very severe issue, because I lost all history while I thought that I made a valid backup. ### Device info **Device:** Nokia 4.2 **Android version:** 11 **Signal version:** 0.0.0 ### Link to debug log
Those are about making the backup file fit on FAT filesystems (storing it in “chunks” that are smaller than the 4GB limit), not incremental backups.

I think it’s worth referring to the following feature request as a possible solution:

Disappearing images / media

I’m nearing 8GB backup files! And it is 95% images. Since I use syncthing to get the file onto off-device storage, I’m taking a double hit in space and bandwidth.

I’d really like a way to address this… incremental is complicated I am sure… and might not solve my problems

But we both might be happy if we could just age out media? Like either start to reduce their resolution after a certain age or more simply just have a setting that says “delete media older then XX” I don’t want to loose text necessarily or I’d just use that feature.

I came to this topic, in a search for the only growing backup files.
I didn’t thought about having incremental backups, but was looking for a way where I could turn on the storage management, but still be able to browse the older messages for example on my desktop.

There seems to be little interest in this topic, so we could think about a work-around for the mean-time. Does someone have ideas?

My original suggestions can easily be staged. For example, just start with the ability to import from more than one backup file and backup only from a certain date. The ‘incremental’ backups can be self-managed.

It’s not really rocket science and there’s probably a dozen other ways to break this down.

Exactly this and comparing to my similar sized Whatsapp backup brought me onto this topic.

As I’m keen on keeping my chat history together, deleting or degrading existing media is not a viable option for me.

My proposal would rather go into direction of mbox vs. maildir (email storage concepts):
Keep each media item as separately encrypted file in storage for the backup. That way, it easily facilitates incremental backups, while keeping all data intact.
Question could be how this relates to performance, but an internal version which is unencrypted and kept for the last 5-6 months (ideally user adjustable) could balance performance vs. Memory usage.

Looking forward to hearing about potential flaws in my idea.

Best,
Chris

posts.name: Sebastian
posts.cooked:
I like the idea.

However, I assume this is also not so easy, since the signal backup specifications change from time to time and this would “force” the signal application to support all previous specifications.

So - if something like this could be done - great!

seb123:

since the signal backup specifications change from time to time and this would “force” the signal application to support all previous specifications

I hope this is already the case as otherwise I would not be able to use a backup from last year with a current signal - or will this break with “backup too old”?

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: It is. Also causes issues for some data migrations.

posts.name: Pablo
posts.cooked: I’d also like to have this so I can import multiple backup files. Some old ones got corrupted but I found a way to recover at least some messages. Still can’t import them as my new messages would be gone.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: This would not help you import multiple backup files.

My 2.5¢:

I enabled backups a little while ago, and noticed that the feature is creating a brand new backup file every single time.

While this means there’s just one file for me to reason about/store and the restoration process has more straightforward UX, I’m kind of freaking out that Signal is issuing 5GB of writes (and growing) to my phone’s storage every time I back up.

My anxiety is not helped by the realisation that I’ve noticed my phone seems to freeze and lag quite a bit more than it used to… right after the time I enabled backups a couple of months ago. It’s a(n ageing) Huawei Mate 20 Pro, which uses an NM card (an obscure SIM card shaped microSD card which are somewhat unobtanium to find in stores), which will be fun to replace… I’m wondering whether this is my sign that my NM card is getting towards the comfortable end of its serviceable lifetime writes

It was really encouraging to hop onto the forum here for the first time and notice Tune backup frequency to reduce flash wear - #15 by Signal.DE right at the top of the list with some recent activity

I wanted to open an adjacent feature request to provide an option to allow for local incremental backup. A moderator let me know my submission was a duplicate, so I’m adding it here as a comment to +1 my support of the idea.

I believe this approach concedes a reasonable amount of UX simplicity for vastly superior technical efficiency, and is the trade-off I would select in a heartbeat myself.

It would be 100% reasonable to put the option behind a modal with like a 10 second delay on the OK button, with a big fat warning explaining that all of the incremental backup files would need to be preserved in order for a restore to complete successfully. Make the UI appropriately frightening. Scare away 90% of users. The current strategy of having one single backup file does make a lot of sense for a lot of reasons.

Of course, scaring off virtually all users would mean the option would have incredibly low long-term uptake, and theoretically at constant risk of being removed.

However, I learned from the linked thread above (also confirmed in discussion further up this thread) that Signal apparently has an incremental backup implementation being developed as part of a paid/tiered online storage option that’s in the works right now.

So, my request is simply that the project strategy around the incremental backup implementation be extended so that the feature gains the capability to save data to the file system as well.

Thanks very much in advance!

link_counts.title: Tune backup frequency to reduce flash wear

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: It’s very likely the improvements will be transferred to file backups as well :)

posts.name: Dave S.
posts.cooked:
Predictable Encryption Keys

I’ve noticed every Signal backup is packed with a different encryption key, meaning tools such as delta compression and rsync can’t benefit from most of the backed up content overlapping.

If the data to be backed up were ordered chronologically and split into fixed-size chunks, and each chunk’s encryption key were a function of the backup PIN and the [hash of the] chunk’s contents, then successive backups would produce mostly-identical chunks, saving a great deal of data transfer and storage. There would be no difference between a regular backup and an incremental backup (see: “single file mode”.)

If it’s difficult to split the messages database, I imagine most of the benefit would be realized if this strategy applied only to media & attachments.

A largely-incremental backup becomes almost free at this point: when storing multiple backups, chunks common to several backups don’t need to be stored or transferred again.

Storage and Transfer

There’s subtlety in deciding how to represent the subset of all chunks which are used by a given backup.

Folder-per-backup: If the chunks comprising a single backup were placed into one folder, we’d have to do something special to ensure each common chunk is stored and transferred once. On COW filesystems, this is easy, but I suspect those aren’t common on Android. Hard links are far more likely to be noticed by tools like rsync and cloud storage clients; the APIs for determining if two files share extents/blocks tend to be system-specific, if not filesystem-specific.

Single Folder & Manifests: putting all chunks in a common folder avoids using features that might not exist on all filesystems, and guarantees common chunks are stored/transferred once. I would suggest that each backup should produce a plain text manifest listing the specific chunks referenced by that backup; I’d be inclined to say this manifest should be both human and machine readable, and write-only from Signal’s point of view.

Regardless of how this is done, we ought to verify that most off-device transfer options, e.g., Google Drive, rsync, etc. realize that chunks of the most recent backup which have already been backed up don’t need to be transferred again.

Single File Mode

If it’s desirable to retain the ability to produce a backup which is a single, self-contained file, I recommend that file be a simple TAR or ZIP of the chunks. Tools like rsync and maybe cloud storage clients might still be able to leverage repeated content, and users could easily convert a single-file backup to the chunked format (or vice versa).
